project_descr: Mandatory Discretionary Review, under the Planning Commission's policy requiring review of dwelling unit mergers, of Building Permit Application No. 2002.10.23.9747, proposing to merge two dwelling units to create a single-family dwelling.
action: continued to march 27, 2003
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, feldstein, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Appeal of Preliminary Negative Declaration for the proposed new construction of 87 affordable housing units, 41 off-street parking spaces (including 3 spaces for the City CarShare Program), a 3,500 square foot childcare facility, a community room, multi-purpose room and offices associated with the residential use, 2,000 square feet of retail space, and one freight-loading space. The proposed project would consist of three separate buildings:  one building would be three-stories tall, or approximately 40 feet in height; a second structure would be five-stories tall, or approximately 50 feet in height; and the third structure would be eight-stories tall, or approximately 80-feet tall. The proposed structures would contain approximately 128,000 gross square feet.  The site is approximately 30,948 square feet in size and located at the northeast corner of Broadway and Battery Streets, with additional frontage on Front Street.  The site currently contains a ground-level asphalt parking lot on a portion of the site and the remainder of the site is vacant.  The site was also the former site of the Embarcadero Freeway off-ramp, and is owned by the City and County of San Francisco.
action: continued to april 3, 2003
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, feldstein, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization to allow [1] the expansion of two existing dwelling units in a M-1 (Light Industrial) Zoning District pursuant to Planning Code Section 215(a) and [2] a revision to a previously built Planned Unit Development (PUD) pursuant to Planning Code Section 304 to allow further modification of Code Sections including the rear yard requirements of Section 134 and the dwelling unit exposure requirements of Section 140. The existing structure contains approximately 1,500 square feet of industrial space in a below-grade basement level, a 1,400 square foot parking garage and 500 square foot outdoor patio on the ground level, and two dwelling units occupying a total of roughly 3,000 square feet on the second and third levels. The proposal would construct a two-story addition atop the existing patio. The project would add approximately 500 square feet on the ground level to the existing industrial space and roughly 250 square feet on the second level for each of the two dwelling units. A 500 square foot outdoor patio would be provided on the roof of the proposed addition.
action: continued to april 3, 2003
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, feldstein, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: 17th AND RHODE ISLAND GROCERY STORE SPECIAL USE SUB-DISTRICT Consideration of an Ordinance amending the San Francisco Planning Code by adding Section 781.10 to create the 17th and Rhode Island Grocery Store Special Use Sub-district, applicable to the newly rezoned NC-3 block (previously M-1) bounded by 17th Street, Rhode Island Street, Mariposa Street and Kansas Street (Assessor's Block 3978, Lot 1), to permit a neighborhood grocery store at 17th and Rhode Island and amending the Section 712 Zoning Control Table; amending Section Map 8 and 8SU of the Zoning Map of the City and County of San Francisco for the property described as Assessor's Block 3978, Lot 1; and adopting findings.
action: continued indefinitely
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, feldstein, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Two Discretionary Review requests, the first initiated by Department Staff, pursuant to Planning Commission residential demolition policy, of Demolition Permit Application Number 2002.04.22.4580, which would demolish an existing single family dwelling, and the second initiated by a member the public, of Building Permit Application Number 2002.04.22.4585, which would construct a new single family dwelling on the same site.
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretionary review and approve the project
note: On February 13, 2003, following public testimony, the Commission closed the public hearing and continued the matter to February 27, 2003, by a vote of +6 -0.  Commissioner Boyd was absent.
action: took discretionary review and disapproved both the demolition permit and building permit
ayes: antonini, bell, feldstein, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use Authorization to allow [1] the construction of 54 dwelling units pursuant to Planning Code Section 215(a), [2] the creation of housing not providing at least 25 percent of the total number of units as affordable units pursuant to Section A(iv) of the Mission District Interim Controls (MDIC; as set forth in Board of Supervisors Resolution Number 500-02), [3] the conversion of a PDR (Production, Distribution, or Repair) use to a non-PDR use pursuant to Section E(v) of the MDIC, and [4] the provision of off-street parking in excess of that which is required pursuant to Section A(x) of the MDIC, in a C-M (Heavy Commercial) Zoning District, the NEMIZ (Northeast Mission Industrial Zone) as defined in Planning Commission Resolution 13794, a Mixed-Use Housing Zone as defined in Planning Commission Resolution 16202, and a 40-X Height and Bulk District. The proposal is to demolish an existing 21,000 square foot industrial building and construct a new structure containing 54 dwelling units on upper levels and 60 off-street parking spaces in a ground level garage. The building would be a maximum of four stories tall (approximately 40 feet in height).
preliminary_recommendation: approve the project with mdoifications and conditions
note: : On March 13, 2003, following public testimony, the Commission closed public hearing and continued the matter to March 20, 2003, instructing the project sponsor to review alternatives for unit mix and affordability components by a vote of +6 -0.  Commissioner Boyd was absent.
action: approve the project with the unit mix of 11, 2-bedrooms; 42 1-bedrooms and one studio
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Finding of Consistency with the General Plan pursuant to § 4.105 of the  San Francisco Charter to install a total of six (6) panel antennas and related equipment at an existing two-story, publicly-used structure (a fire station) as part of Cingular Wireless' wireless telecommunications network ... Wireless Telecommunications Services (WTS) Facilities Siting Guidelines the proposal is a Location Preference 1 (Preferred Location - Publicly-Used Structure).

lines: this site is a preference one and is a collocation site
the purpose of this site is to provide coverage to the excelsior district

action: found consistent with the general plan
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, feldstein, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Request for Conditional Use authorization pursuant to Section 209.6(b) and 234 of the Planning Code to install a total of six (6) panel antennas and related equipment at an existing two-story, publicly-used structure (a fire station) as part of Cingular Wireless' wireless telecommunications network. As per the City & County of San Francisco's Wireless Telecommunications Services (WTS) Facilities Siting Guidelines the proposal is a Location Preference 1 (Preferred Location - Publicly-Used Structure).
action: approved with conditions as proposed
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, feldstein, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: - Staff presentation and community comments on the public review draft of the Market and Octavia Neighborhood Plan, distributed on December 17, 2002 as part of the Department's Better Neighborhoods Program - comment gathering only; no approval actions.  Information available at
speakers: ramona davis norman rolfe, howard strassner, robert meyers, ashley hamlett, ron hartman, mike ellis, christopher pederson, anthony faber, robin levitt, jon twichell, john keazer, ron miguel, kate white, heather thomson, marcy adelman, clark seally, judy macks, matile ruthschild, nolan madison, jan faulkner, patricia walkup, nancy brundy, stefan hastrup, ingrid summerfield, gary gee, calvin welch, george orleas, sean kiegran

speaker_statements.speaker: ramona davies
speaker_statements.descr: northern california presbyterian homes and services
lines: supports the rainbow adult housing community’s vision to treat parcels o and p as a single entity
wants the plan modified to allow a center providing senior housing and services for the lgbt community

speaker_statements.speaker: norman rolfe
lines: generally supports the plan for an urban neighborhood
urges making 1:1 the maximum parking and having no minimum; allow zero parking when desired

speaker_statements.speaker: howard strassner
lines: strongly supports the plan
argues it returns to patterns where shops operated without parking
says transit cannot succeed if parking is continually provided

speaker_statements.speaker: robert meyers
lines: reviewed the draft and compliments staff on an excellent, readable document
says the plan has superb goals and residents are eager for approval
requests a slight increase in height limits
urges continued support for staff

speaker_statements.speaker: ashley hamlett
lines: calls the plan and process fabulous
notes strong community involvement that has boosted participation

speaker_statements.speaker: ron hartman
lines: presented a diagram showing 50-foot heights are too tall in some areas
supports 50 feet around octavia but 40 feet on the uphill sides of fell and oak and all of laguna
looks forward to timely implementation

speaker_statements.speaker: mike ellis
lines: commends staff on the plan
recommends revising 50-foot height areas that would be out of character with the street
asks not to extend hickory alley and prefers a pedestrian greenbelt

speaker_statements.speaker: christopher pederson
lines: very enthusiastic about the plan
says the neighborhood’s central location and transit options make it a great place to live
supports limiting parking and improving transit access to the arts

speaker_statements.speaker: anthony faber
lines: strongly supports the plan
appreciated the community plan meetings

speaker_statements.speaker: robin levitt
lines: read and supports the plan because it addresses neighbors’ issues
says it reflects outcomes of community meetings
highlights reduced parking and appropriate density as key

speaker_statements.speaker: jim haas
lines: calls the plan excellent for enhancing the residential neighborhood
notes institutions attract patrons who drive from outside the city
wants the plan amended to account for these institutions and their parking impacts

speaker_statements.speaker: jon twichell
lines: notes the civic center area’s mixed uses: residents, government employees, and performing arts
urges accounting for peak times in studies
says many already use transit, but performing arts peaks still draw drivers

speaker_statements.speaker: john keazer
speaker_statements.descr: director of electronic media, san francisco symphony
lines: asks for careful review of parking impacts on performing arts patrons and institutions
expresses concern about parking and traffic reports

speaker_statements.speaker: ron miguel
lines: compliments staff on handling the plan
praises extensive community input
describes the neighborhood as unusual for seeking increased density and reduced parking
acknowledges civic center parking issues

speaker_statements.speaker: kate white
lines: thrilled with the plan and neighborhood enthusiasm
credits the department for educating the community
says the plan is specific and zoning is clear

speaker_statements.speaker: heather thomson
lines: fully supports the plan
says it will increase housing density while improving traffic and transit
urges commission support

speaker_statements.speaker: marcy adelman
lines: stresses the importance of housing for lgbt elders
says the plan generally reflects neighborhood desires
concerned about parcels o and p being subdivided, which would block a mixed-use, community-serving hub

speaker_statements.speaker: clark seally
lines: finds the plan confusing about division of parcels o and p
warns that subdividing them would prevent a community-serving organization

speaker_statements.speaker: judy macks
lines: notes plans to expand their housing organization
asks to revise the market/octavia plan to allow flexibility for expanding organizations

speaker_statements.speaker: matile ruthschild
lines: as a senior lesbian, wants housing where she can feel comfortable among peers
asks the commission to support senior housing in the market street area
says current plans for parcels o and p would hinder the rock organization’s expansion

speaker_statements.speaker: nolan madson
lines: calls the plan excellent despite remaining details
supports the rock project and recommends parcels o and p not be combined
fears generic loft condos if lots are divided

speaker_statements.speaker: jan faulkner
lines: supports previous speakers’ points
recently moved from berkeley to be closer to her community and wishes she could move into it

speaker_statements.speaker: patricia walkup
lines: notes a shortage of green spaces for people to gather
wants streets and sidewalks to function as gathering places
supports reducing parking requirements for new development
calls for active storefronts rather than blank garages
emphasizes transit-first for van ness and mission
asks support for these elements, saying the plan fails without them

speaker_statements.speaker: nancy brundy
lines: supports the rock group’s position to keep lots o and p undivided
notes special needs in the lgbt community
asks for flexibility to maximize the site’s potential

speaker_statements.speaker: stefan hastrup
lines: attended nearly all better neighborhoods workshops
says the plan is what the neighborhood has awaited for years
wants swift implementation
states housing is more important than garages
commends the department for listening

speaker_statements.speaker: ingrid summerfield
lines: calls the plan excellent and hopes it proceeds
concerned about height limits in the laguna/oak/fell area
hopes developers find creative solutions
supports the rock project but wants height limited

speaker_statements.speaker: gary gee
lines: compliments staff on a great document
submitted a document detailing his concerns

speaker_statements.speaker: calvin welch
lines: says his group pushed the mayor to fund this planning
notes they did neighborhood affordable housing before the department did
happy to move forward but stunned by plan language
argues the affordable housing policies overemphasize homeownership
states the document is not properly written and does not reflect commission policy

speaker_statements.speaker: george orleas
lines: thanks the commission and community for their work
supports senior affordable housing given many seniors are unhoused

speaker_statements.speaker: sean kiegran
lines: says housing is sacrificed to satisfy a 1:1 parking ratio
encourages allowing less than 1:1 parking

action: meeting held to receive public comment. no action required by the commission

project_descr: Request for conditional use authorization to convert residential hotel rooms to nonresidential use and to establish a tourist hotel use. The existing building, the Baldwin Hotel, contains 61 residential hotel rooms, of which 45 are vacant.  The proposed project is to convert the vacant residential hotel rooms to tourist hotel rooms.  There will be no physical expansion of the existing building.
action: without hearing, item continued to may 8, 2003
ayes: antonini, bell, boyd, hughes, s. lee, w. lee

action: the acting zoning administrator closed the public hearing and has taken this matter under advisement

project_descr: Public Hearing on Draft Environmental Impact Report. The project proposes demolition of three existing two- to six-story structures on the project site, totaling about 173,650 gross square feet (gsf), and the building of a 58-story, 605 foot-tall, mixed userdevelopment, totaling about 1,156,500 gsf.  The net change in area for the site would be an increase of about 982,850 gsf.  The proposed development would contain about 130,560 gsf of office space; a 120-suite extended-stay hotel (about 164,800 gsf); 320 residential units (about 551,000 gsf); ground-floor retail and restaurant space (about 9,400 gsf); a publicly accessible atrium (about 6,400 gsf); and lobbies (about 4,340 gsf).  Building services would occupy about 33,400 gsf and mechanical space would occupy about 104,840 gsf.  There would be three off-street loading docks and four off-street van spaces, and 400 spaces of underground parking and vehicular circulation on four levels (about 151,760 gsf).  The site includes Lots 1 and 17 on Assessor's Block 3719.  The project requires approval as new construction in a C-3 District under Planning Code Section 309; a Bulk Limits:  Special Exceptions in C-3 District authorization under Section 272; a Height Limits:  Special Exception for Upper Tower Extensions in S Districts authorization under Section 263.9; Conditional Use authorization for a Major (Nonaccessory) Parking Garage Not Open to the Public under Section 223(p); Conditional Use authorization for Hotel Use in a C-3-O District under Section 216(c);  transfer of development rights in a C-3 District authorization under Section 128; a lot line adjustment to merge the existing lots by the Public Works Department; and approval by the Board of Supervisors to eliminate the mid-block pedestrian crosswalk across Fremont Street between Mission and Natoma Streets.
preliminary_recommendation: public hearing to receive comments. no action required

speaker_statements.speaker: norman rolfe
lines: says proposition h would extend the transbay terminal and this project conflicts with that expansion
questions the assumptions about housing demand
calls the environmental report faulty and based on incorrect assumptions

speaker_statements.speaker: ian lewis
lines: the union will submit comments on the eir
says the eir inadequately reviews projects with a hotel component
warns job-related growth would burden city social services
urges considering the project in context of the transbay terminal and caltrain station, beyond section 303
says better coordination among area projects would reduce problems

speaker_statements.speaker: john carney
lines: says the project requires seven variances and should not be on the agenda
argues environmental review should address a version without fundamental variances across seven codes
claims it is out of scale for the neighborhood even if technically allowed

speaker_statements.speaker: sue hestor
lines: asks to remove the pedestrian bridge as part of the project
says the project will bring many pedestrians into the area
considers the building too tall

action: public hearing held. no action required.

project_descr: Mandatory Discretionary Review under the Planning Commission's policy requiring review of housing demolition of Demolition Permit Application No. 9917935 proposing to demolish a two-story single-family residence. The project also proposes the construction of a new four-story, three-family dwelling on the site.
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretionary review and approve the demolition permit application

speaker_statements.speaker: sue hestor
lines: a soundness report should be required as it always has been

speaker_statements.speaker: rev. arnold townsend
lines: the reason there is no soundness report is because at the time of the application it was not required

first_action: take discretionary review and deny demolition permit
action: item continued indefinitely
ayes: antonini, bell, feldstein, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2002 0828 5143, to construct a two-story, horizontal addition, to the front of the rear building (dwelling) on the property and to construct a second story, vertical addition, to the front building (garage)
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretionary review and approve the project
speakers: leticia redondo, mike hutchinson, corazon metraparel, sean kriegan

speaker_statements.speaker: leticia redondo
lines: concerned her kitchen window will be blocked by the proposed property, removing her main source of daylight and forcing electric light all day
states garages are intended for cars, not people; worries a simple stove or hot plate could turn the downstairs into an apartment

speaker_statements.speaker: mike hutchinson
lines: concerned the entire structure will block light to his whole house, not just the kitchen
claims the sponsor did construction without permits and only obtained them after neighbors complained
asks why the sponsor cannot build toward the back instead of building up

speaker_statements.speaker: corazon metraparel
lines: asks the commission to approve her project because she has met all requirements
says a light well will prevent the window from being blocked
told the dr requestor, ms. rodondo, she could build a roof for her
notes a notice of special restriction has already been issued on her property

speaker_statements.speaker: sean kriegan
lines: warns that protecting existing property-line windows will limit housing production
says the sponsor already designed a cut-out and believes it should suffice for the dr requestor

action: Did not take Discretionary Review and approved the building application with the requirement to record a Notice of Special Restriction limiting the use of the subject property to single-family residential use.
ayes: antonini, bell, feldstein, s. lee, w. lee

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2002.05.08.6090 proposing to construct a new two-story vertical and horizontal addition to the existing single-story over garage building with an attic level.  The project proposes an increase from one to two dwelling units.  The project is in an RH-2 (Residential, House, Two-Family) District with a 40-X Height and Bulk Designation.  The proposal also requires a front setback Variance for the second story, which will be considered by the Zoning Administrator.
preliminary_recommendation: take discretionary review and approve the project with modifications
speakers: kris gardner, john carney, dick millet, peter rudolfi, julie jackson, foster reed, chris cole, ches herbert, bobbi frioli, lewis goldhammer, richard katz, william walters, pete loskotoff, bill canihan

speaker_statements.speaker: kris gardner
lines: encouraged that the sponsor wants to expand the building
says the proposed design is not compatible with other homes on the street
notes the proposed design is a 235% increase over the original but is treated only as an alteration
agrees with planning to reduce height by eliminating the top story to keep with the block face

speaker_statements.speaker: john carney
lines: agrees with the planning department’s recommendation to remove the top floor

speaker_statements.speaker: dick millet
lines: was glad to hear planning’s comments
says scale is much better after adopting the department’s recommendations

speaker_statements.speaker: peter rudolfi
lines: argues builders should not build to the full extent of the envelope
says the design is out of character with other buildings on potrero hill
compliments planning on their study and recommendation

speaker_statements.speaker: julie jackson
lines: says the project is significantly out of scale with the block
supports planning’s recommendation to reduce the building’s height and mass

speaker_statements.speaker: foster reed
lines: notes this is the third project on the block
argues projects like this should not reach this stage
warns the neighborhood will be destroyed if approved as presented

speaker_statements.speaker: chris cole
lines: displayed a large model showing alternative designs that would avoid impacting the dr requestor

speaker_statements.speaker: ches herbert
lines: receives a lot of sunlight in home and yard; says the project would block this light
says the proposed rear alteration is also disruptive
recommends reducing the pitched roof to further reduce height

speaker_statements.speaker: bobbi frioli
lines: concerned about privacy issues

speaker_statements.speaker: richard katz

concerned the project would change neighborhood character and not respect the blockface

speaker_statements.speaker: pete loskotoff

action: following public testimony, the commission closed the public hearing and continued this item to april 3, 2003. Both Discretionary Review requestor and Project Sponsor were asked to explore possible alternatives to the plans.
ayes: antonini, bell, s. lee, w. lee
